Although no attempt was made to investigate the issue of the gastric emptying rate, we showed that concurrent administration of urea and citric acid, in combination with flavor enhancers and stabilizers, led to a marked discrimination between H. pylori positive and H. pylori negative patients. In the present study, involving a large number of H. pylori positive participants, the mean or median (which in this case were virtually identical) of the DOB responses may be assumed to provide a comparatively accurate index of the extent of interaction between substrate and enzyme. A review of the literature involving studies that reported a mean DOB value in H. pylori infected patients, has suggested an enhanced discriminatory capacity of the Helikit™ relative to other protocols (Table 3). We contend that it is this capacity for discrimination that ultimately determines the acceptability and usefulness of the test.
